questions.text: A 32-year P3 comes to OPD with AUB. Menarche was at age 13 years, and she has had regular cycles till 1 year ago. She then began to have delayed periods every 45-60 days with heavy bleeding, clots but no cramping. She has not had her period in 4 months. She has no hot flushes, acne, or abnormal hair growth. She takes levo-thyroxine for hypothyroidism and has had a tubal ligation done. Height is 160 cm, weight is 120kg. P/S is normal. Bimanual exam is limited by body habitus. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Lab tests are as follows: TSH- 2.9, Prolactin: 16, LH: 15 What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This patient is having anovulatory cycles. This is because She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels. This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels. This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)
  • • This patient is having anovulatory cycles. This is because She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels. This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels. This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)
  • • She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels. This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels. This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)
  • • She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels.
  • • This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels.
  • • This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • This is not primary ovarian insufficiency as there are no hot flushes which mean estrogen levels are normal/ high Her TSH levels are normal so this is not hypothyroidism Leiomyoma presents as heavy bleeding in regular cycles.
  • • This is not primary ovarian insufficiency as there are no hot flushes which mean estrogen levels are normal/ high
  • • Her TSH levels are normal so this is not hypothyroidism
  • • Leiomyoma presents as heavy bleeding in regular cycles.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anovular cycles are common in women with high BMI
  • ➤ Anovular cycles are common in women with high BMI

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This is an image of an intra-uterine device Contra-indications to Intrauterine Devices include Pregnancy Puerperal Sepsis Septic Abortion Unexplained vaginal bleeding Gestational trophoblastic disease Cervical cancer Endometrial cancer Distorted uterine cavity (Pre-existing uterine fibroids that distort the uterine cavity may be incompatible with insertion and proper placement of the IUD) PID
  • • This is an image of an intra-uterine device
  • • Contra-indications to Intrauterine Devices include
  • • Pregnancy
  • • Puerperal Sepsis
  • • Septic Abortion
  • • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • • Cervical cancer
  • • Endometrial cancer
  • • Distorted uterine cavity (Pre-existing uterine fibroids that distort the uterine cavity may be incompatible with insertion and proper placement of the IUD)
  • • PID
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Option A. Adenomyosis : Adenomyosis, a condition where the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium) breaks through the muscle wall of the uterus, is not a contraindication for IUD use, it helps in reducing the heavy menstrual bleeding associated with adenomyosis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Adenomyosis
  • • Option B . Large Submucosal Fibroid (Correct Answer): A large submucosal fibroid, which protrudes into the uterine cavity, can distort the uterine cavity and interfere with the proper placement and function of an IUD. This can increase the risk of expulsion, malposition, or even perforation, making it a contraindication for IUD use.
  • • Option B
  • • Large Submucosal Fibroid
  • • Option C . Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia : Simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is generally not a contraindication for IUD use. In fact, hormonal IUDs that release progestin can be part of the treatment plan for endometrial hyperplasia.
  • • Option C
  • • Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia
  • • Option D . Nulliparous Woman : While historically there was hesitation in using IUDs in nulliparous women, current evidence supports the safety and efficacy of IUDs in this population.
  • • Option D
  • • Nulliparous Woman

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Large submucosal fibroids that distort the uterine cavity are a contraindication for IUD use due to the potential for complications such as expulsion or perforation. Other conditions like adenomyosis, simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, or being a nulliparous woman are not contraindications for IUD use.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Gynecology 3 rd edition page 109
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Gynecology 3 rd edition page 109

questions.text: The Anti-progesterone compound RU-486 is effective for inducing abortion if the duration of pregnancy is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 63 days

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • RU-486 is Mifepristone and along with Misoprostol, it is used for medical methods of abortion.
  • • RU-486 is Mifepristone and along with Misoprostol, it is used for medical methods of abortion.
  • • A combi pack of mifepristone and misoprostol (one tablet of mifepristone 200mg and four tablets of misoprostol 200mcg each) has been approved by the Central Drugs Standard Control Organization, Directorate General of Health Services, for the medical termination of pregnancy up to n ee9ks (63 days) LMP in December 2008 However; CAC Training & Service Delivery Guidelines, 2016 by MoHFW, GoI recommends its use up to 49 days (7 weeks) in public sector sites, in line with the MTP Rules 2003. A proposed amendment to the MTP Act, 1971, to increase the gestation limit for MMA to 9 weeks in public sector sites is under process. Till the proposal is approved , MMA in public health facility would be allowed only up to 7 weeks. So if the question asks approved for use in public health facility, the answer will be 49 days, but it can be given till 9 weeks of pregnancy

questions.text: As per the 2021 amendment of the MTP act, the upper limit of gestational age for terminating a fetus with substantial anomalies is:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Very Important
  • • Very Important
  • • As per the 2021 MTP amendment: act, a few important changes which you have to know are that the upper limit of gestational age has been increased as per the following:
  • • Till 20 weeks for original indications (maternal indication, fetal indication, failure of contraception and rape); opinion of 1 RMP required Till 24 weeks for select indications like fetal maformation, rape, humanitarian grounds and maternal diability; opinion of 2 RMPS required After 24 weeks: Only for substantial fetal malformations (No upper limit but this has to be allowed by a medical board)
  • • Till 20 weeks for original indications (maternal indication, fetal indication, failure of contraception and rape); opinion of 1 RMP required
  • • Till 24 weeks for select indications like fetal maformation, rape, humanitarian grounds and maternal diability; opinion of 2 RMPS required
  • • After 24 weeks: Only for substantial fetal malformations (No upper limit but this has to be allowed by a medical board)

questions.text: Persistence of endometriosis is directly dependent on which of the following hormones?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Estrogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic state

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometriosis is a Hyperestrogenic state. Estrogen facilitates the growth of the ectopic endometrial glands. Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent, chronic inflammatory disease with aberrant growth of ectopic endometrial tissue. The disturbed molecular mechanisms in this disease are yet to be completely defined. However, suspected underpinnings include an environment estrogen dominance, estrogen dependence, and progesterone resistance within implants; inflammation; escape from immune clearance; local invasion and neurovascular development; and genetic predisposition.
  • ➤ Endometriosis is a Hyperestrogenic state.
  • ➤ Estrogen facilitates the growth of the ectopic endometrial glands.
  • ➤ Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent, chronic inflammatory disease with aberrant growth of ectopic endometrial tissue.
  • ➤ The disturbed molecular mechanisms in this disease are yet to be completely defined. However, suspected underpinnings include an environment estrogen dominance, estrogen dependence, and progesterone resistance within implants; inflammation; escape from immune clearance; local invasion and neurovascular development; and genetic predisposition.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 233, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Obstetric conjugate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet
  • ➤ Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet
  • ➤ Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter
  • ➤ Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate. Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm):
  • ➤ Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate.
  • ➤ Obstetric conjugate (10 cm):
  • ➤ Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.
  • ➤ Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm):
  • ➤ Transverse Diameter (13 cm)
  • ➤ Transverse Diameter (13 cm)
  • ➤ Distance between the farthest two points on the iliopectineal line. It is the largest diameter of pelvic inlet
  • ➤ Distance between the farthest two points on the iliopectineal line.
  • ➤ It is the largest diameter of pelvic inlet

  • ➤ Oblique Diameters (12 cm)
  • ➤ Right oblique diameter: Passes from right sacroiliac joint to left ilio-pubiceminence Left oblique diameter: Passes from left sacroiliac joint to right ilio-pubic eminence

questions.text: A 30 y comes to OPD for evaluation of absent periods. The patient had a vaginal delivery 8 months ago and she’s not had her period since delivery. Her postpartum course was complicated by secondary PPH requiring blood transfusion and a D & E for retained products. At a visit, 2 months ago, the patient was started on combined OCPs, and she has not had vaginal bleeding. Prior to this pregnancy she had regular monthly cycles. She also has increased fatigue. She is not lactating and is bottle feeding her baby. There is no headache, galactorrhoea, or hot flushes. BMI is 31, vitals are normal. Pelvic examination shows clear vaginal discharge and well rugate vagina. The uterus is small and anteverted. UPT is negative. FSH and TSH are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 34-year nulliparous woman presents to the OPD. She complains of pelvic heaviness. She also mentions that her periods have been increasingly heavy in amount and she has to take a pain killer on the 1 st 2 days of her period due to excessive pain. The periods are otherwise regular. On examination, there is an irregular mass palpated abdominally which is about the size of an 18 weeks gravid uterus. On bimanual exam, the same irregular mass is felt and there is transmitted mobility. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Leiomyoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp. On examination, this is a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids) The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous
  • • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp.

  • • The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous

  • • There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses)

Fibroid polyps usually present with inter menstrual bleeding or irregular bleeding In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents to the OPD with excess facial hair for 6 months and delayed menstrual cycles. On evaluation, levels of free testosterone are increased. An ultrasound reveals normal uterus and normal ovaries on USG. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Polycystic ovarian syndrome/ disease (PCOS/PCOD) is a disorder of chronically abnormal ovarian function (oligo/anovulation) and hyperandrogenism frequently associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, and hirsutism. Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD: As per this criterion, at least 2 of 3 should be present :
  • • Polycystic ovarian syndrome/ disease (PCOS/PCOD) is a disorder of chronically abnormal ovarian function (oligo/anovulation) and hyperandrogenism frequently associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, and hirsutism.
  • • Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD: As per this criterion, at least 2 of 3 should be present :
  • • Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD:
  • • Oligo/anovulation (causes oligomenorrhea, 2 0 amenorrhea, and infertility) Hyperandrogenism: Biochemical or clinical (increased serum androgens or acne, hirsutism) 12 or more than 12 follicle 2-9 mm in size present within 1 or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume > 10 mL (pearl necklace pattern).
  • • Oligo/anovulation (causes oligomenorrhea, 2 0 amenorrhea, and infertility)
  • • Hyperandrogenism: Biochemical or clinical (increased serum androgens or acne, hirsutism)
  • • 12 or more than 12 follicle 2-9 mm in size present within 1 or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume > 10 mL (pearl necklace pattern).
  • • USG appearance of polycystic ovaries
  • • As the patient in the question satisfies first 2 criteria, she is a case of PCOS
  • • As the patient in the question satisfies first 2 criteria, she is a case of PCOS
  • • let's consider the other options:
  • • let's consider the other options:
  • • Option. A. Adrenal Hyperplasia : Adrenal hyperplasia, particularly congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), can cause symptoms similar to PCOS, including hirsutism and menstrual irregularities, due to elevated androgens. However, it is usually diagnosed earlier in life and often has other associated adrenal hormone abnormalities.
  • • Option. A.
  • • Adrenal Hyperplasia
  • • Option. B. Idiopathic Hirsutism : Idiopathic hirsutism refers to hirsutism (excess hair growth) in the absence of any identifiable hormonal imbalance or ovarian/adrenal gland disorder. Given the increased free testosterone levels in this patient, idiopathic hirsutism is less likely.
  • • Option. B.
  • • Idiopathic Hirsutism
  • • Option. D. Testosterone Secreting Tumor : While a testosterone-secreting tumor can cause increased androgen levels and symptoms like hirsutism, these tumors are rare. The more common presentation of such tumors would include rapid onset of symptoms and markedly elevated testosterone levels.
  • • Option. D.
  • • Testosterone Secreting Tumor

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the pathophysiology of placenta accrete syndromes?

options.label: A
options.text: The abnormal adherence is due to partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer

options.label: B
options.text: Microscopically, the placental villi are found attached to smooth muscle fibers

options.label: C
options.text: There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of Placenta accrete syndromes in the same pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

questions.correct_answer: D. About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta, The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored. Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells. Factors implicated in the pathogenesis An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect
  • • The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.
  • • It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta,
  • • The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage
  • • This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • • If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.
  • • Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells.
  • • Factors implicated in the pathogenesis An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section
  • • like a history of a previous cesarean section
  • • Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness”
  • • Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed
  • • There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
